Wow, I had no idea that someone could come up with a statement that the Universe expands an contracts every billion years. Come on Charles. Stop smoking the good stuff. The questions is all messed up. It should have stated: Is the Universe expanding or contracting. And the correct answer is that it is expanding and doing so at an accelerating pace. No need to go into the details. But at the current rate, when the last star goes Supernova in about 100 trillion years, the universe will have expanded to something in the range of 10e+35 light years. And it may be much more based on how much longer the accelerated expansions lasts. To put this in perspective, the current universe is 93 billion light years across. To equate this to 10e+35, imagine this. There are approximately 3 x 10e+26 drops of water on our planet, including he oceans, lakes, rivers, toilet bowls, water heaters, swimming pools and bottles water at the supermarkets. That is a lot of drops. Now line those drops up next to each other. At 1/4 inch per drop, it takes 7.5 million drop to make 1 mile, So all those drops would add up to 4 x 10e+17 miles. That amounts to 65,000 light years, or about from here to the other side of the Milky Way We are not done :) For 10e+35 drops, the line of water drops would extend to 6.5 x 10e+14 light years: 65-trillion light years (650,000,000,000,000) ! And remember, we’re only talking water drops. now look at 10e+35 light years … Yes numbers get mind boggling when you start realizing the size of things in the universe today and in the future.
